1)internal navigability - ability to walk around in a scenario 
without getting lost - only 2 examples of sceanrios that don't match 
this criteria, 'The Stairs' from tevfifty and 'The Cellars' from 
tevfifty.
 
2)mobility - wide enough spaces to allow either a large slime or a
fire elemental go through fairly easily.  biggest examles of one 
that doesn't fit: 'The Labrinth"
 
3)quirks - negative factors.   for example, in most of my scenarios,
chain lightning can't be used without waiting forever.

4) Challenge vs reward
if there is too much money in an easy scenario or too little in a 
hard one. for "reward scenarios" which give you a lot of money at the 
end of a campaign for doing the whole campaign (by campaign i mean a 
group of scenarios like the tevfifty) this could be stretched but you 
might want to begin with a teleporter maze that the last scenario 
tells you how to get through so no-one just skips to the $$$ scenario

5)make them interesting and not just impossible
if it's just monsters banging they're heads against you and 
nothing for you to do but hit the fire key this get a bad rating (or 
level or number or whatever) but if you actually make choices by 
having different goals or different means of achieving a goal or if 
there is something that makes the scenario unique then this gets a 
good, um, thing. if everyone makes 50 of these levels then we'll run 
out of ideas so if anywhere between 1/3 and 2/3 of ones scenarios are 
like this that suffices.

6)theme - is there a consistent theme to the set of scenarios, or are 
they loosely tired together?

The only big thing is working out scales for each factor.

I agree with the new factors,; of course, most of my scenarios might 
flunk tests #4 and #5.

I will try to get around to working on 'The Weakest Link' scenario 
this weeked.  After that, most of my scenarios will be single 
character oriented to keep things consistent with my theme.
